bibl.title: Hosaye Sakaguchi v. Henry M. White. Type of document

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the matter of the Petition of No.5959 Hosaye Sakaguchi, MEMORANDUM OF for a Writ of habeas Corpus.

We desire to add to the contencion set out in the petition herein, the further contentions that the Board of Special Inquiry was not legally constituted. It appears from the record in the body of the return that the Board was composed of Frank S. Mounlion and B.A. Hunter, inspectors, and Wilbur S. Pacterson, stenographer,
Section 17 of the Immigration Act of Feb. 5 1917, provinces:

"That each Board of Special Inquiry skill consists of three members who shall be selected from such of the immigrant officers in the service as the Commissioner General of Immigration with the approval of the Secretary of Labor, shall from time to time designate as quialified to serve or such Boards."
The Board in the insuant cause appears to have been composed of two inpectors and a stenographer. We submit that this does not constitute a legal Board.
J.S. vs Redfern, 150 Fed. 500.
The statute uses the term officer, We submit that a stenographer is not an officer.
A pension clerk i not an official of the United States so as to disqualify him from membership in the state legislature.
State vs. Mason, 55 N.E. 167

A clerk in the office of the Supervisor of Internal Revenue under Revised Statutes Sec. 3130 is not an officer of the United States and as such required to take the Oath of Office prescribed by Section 1756 R.S.U.S.
Hedrick vs. U.S. 16 St. Claims page 55-100 U.S. vs. Schlierholz, 137 Fed. 316 Martin vs. U.S., 168 Fed. 198 U.S. vs. Haus, 157 Fed. 211

If the Board was illegaly constituted as we contend it was, it was without power to hear or determine the matter, and this sets the whole matter at large, and the court will determine the status of the petitioner upon the record as- to law and facts.
U.S. vs. Smith, 124 U.S. 525 31 L. Ed. 534.

Under the treaty between the United States and Japan, there is no impediment to the landing of the petitioner. The only restriction upon the landing and entry of Japanese immigrants is what of Agreement that no passports will be issued by the Japanese Government to laborers. It follows, therefore, that if the passport of petitioner was regular, she is entitled to land, unless some valid objections appears. No objection appears except the pretext that because the husbanf of the petitioner declined to have more to do with her, she was likely to become a public charge.
A few words as to the fact that the husband refused to have anything more to do with the petitioner.

The marriage of the petitioner and her husband is valid in Japan, and therfore valid everywhere else. The husband can not avoid his legal liability to support his wife by merely declining to have any more to do with her.

By general laws of the land the husband is bound to support his wife, and requires no argument that he can not divest himself of this liability by merely refusing to receive his wife after causing her to be brought to the United States.
The finding of a majority of the Board of Special Inquiry (2)

that petitioner is liable to become a public charge is not born out by the evidence. The brother-in-law and the sister of the petitioner have in the most unqualified terms undertaken the support petitioner.

It appears from Sec. 5375 Rem. & Bal. Code, that a sister is liable for the support of a poor relative- sister. It follows, wherefore, that independently of the desire and willingness of petitioner's sister and brother-in-law to take care of her, they are under legal liability so to do. The finding of a majority of the Board of Special Inquiry ignores this feature of the case, and is to that extent a denial of a fair trial.

It is judicially settled that the Court will look into the record and will determine from the facts in the record of the immigrant office whether there is any legal ground to support the finding of liability to become a public charge.
Gegiow vs. Uhl, 239 U.S. 3 30 L Ed. 114
To the same effect is
Pazos vs. Redfern, 150 Fed. 500 U.S. vs. Martin, 193 Fed. 759 Sprung vs. Martin, 152 Fed. 230 U.S. vs Nakashima, 160 Fed. 842

A reading of these cases will disclose that rulings of the Court are to the effect that where a person is in good health, has sufficient apparent earning ability to support himself or herself, they can not be adjudged likely to become a public charge.
The same effect is U.S. vs. Suekichi, 199 Fed. 751

In the case at her, in addition to the support offered by the brother and sister, it appears from the record that the petitioner is skilled in sewing and in the making of artificial flowers, and that she is able to suport herself in these occupations.
We submit that the finding of the Board of Special Inquiry (3)
is arbitrary, and does violence to the admitted and proven facts, and denies to petitioner a fair trial, and the writ should be granted and the petitioner permitted to enter.
James Kiefer Attorney for petitioner.
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT Western District of Washington NORTHEN DIVISION
APR 21 1921 F.M. HARSHBERGER, CLERK.
